description.text:
This is a simple version of the ubiquitous spinning toy. Only need a ball bearing, better if it is ceramic.
I bought this:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1pc-Hand-Spinner-bearing-Si3N4-black-ceramic-BSB-Speed-Swiss-Bearing-608z-Skateboard-scooter-wheel-Freeline/32628486005.html

The balls I use are from a old big broken ball bearing that I dissamble. The balls are 17mm wide. You can use a marble.

Printer:

kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Note: Inserting the balls.

I use a hair dryer, to carefully hot the thin part of the ball support and then insert the ball on the hole. Once the ball is in I press the plastic walls against the ball.

This is a printed 4 cylinder 12V motor.
See: http://youtu.be/xJX4PsNLRdk
Based on the principle of a solenoid motor. I'm busy with cleaning up all the files and fixing a manual. (see: help.odp)
For this moment it is in a prototype phase.
Suggestions and questions are very welcome.

BOM of printed materials only
bearing_bracket (2)
bearing_bracket_top(2)
duplo_sensor_bracket (2)
duplo_sensor_bracket_top (2)
encoder_disk (2)

title: Fliptrix - customizable print-in-place dot matrix style flip board display
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Fliptrix

A customizable print in place dot matrix style flip board display

Updates

  • fixed 'cube' option thanks to @Neon22
  • v1.1 - improved plate_holders, adjusted default tolerances for better results on low end printers, renamed variables

About

This is my first project in OpenSCAD.
I've always liked to play with post-it notes, dot matrix displays, pixel art editors, etc. so I've decided to make my own, real life pixel-art board to play around. I find it much more fun to use than fidget widgets which are so popular these days.

Since I'm lazy the main goal was to make it print fully assembled in one go and printable on single extruder 3d printer.

I think this could be quite nice to use for stop motion animation.

Parameters

Just a few tricky things with parameters.

  • thickness (height of print; z-axis)
    • cannot be larger than plate_width
    • when it is equal to plate_width and plates_type is set to 'rounded' you'll end up having cylidnders instead of plates which might be fun as well (but you might need brim)
  • plate_holders
    I didn't have much trouble with plates flipping on their own (e.g. when board gets shaken) but for high resolution prints probably they will so I've added the option to make a snap in plate holders. Option tested, seems to work.
  • horizontal_gap
    It must be lower than half of row_space and half of col_space

In practice

As you can see on pictures it works (disregard print quality :) ).
All prints have been made with 0.2 mm layer, 0.4 mm nozzle, extrusion width 0.5 mm.

  • Small black & white print - plate size 10x10 mm (this works best in my opinion)
  • Blue & yellow print - plate size 8x8 mm
  • "I ❤ 3D" print - plate size 6x6 mm

Sample STL included in case you don't want to use customizer just to try it out.

Future considerations

  • Probably improve plate_holders after testing - seems done
  • Improve printing with long bridges (for larger values of plate_height)
  • Add connectors to combine multiple frames
  • For multi extruder printers
    • print frame in a different color than plates (for better contrast)
    • add 3 and 4 sided plates... wow, much color

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

If you are using single extruder printer remember to change filament around 50% .

Note that plate_height param that defines single plate height influences also the bridge that's printed inside plate so large values may not work out well.

I have printed with 100% infill but it might work ok with lower values.

I recommend printing small board (e.g. 2x2) first to test your setup.

  1. If the display plate and frame is glued together either play around with printer calibration or increase horizontal_gap.
  2. If plate is not glued to frame but doesn't flip increase hole_gap parameter in customizer (not the actual layer height in slicer).
  3. If plate is neither glued to frame nor to the bridge inside and you've used plate_holders they might be blocking it. Try using single plateholder or none.

Anything other than manually flipping plates should not be required.
When flipping a plate for the first time it's probably better to do it gently, although I have not broken a single one even when significant force was applied.

If you decide to print it out would be fun to see a photo of your creation so please consider adding it with "I made one" :)

Have fun!

author: swiniak

description.text:
At 20,237 ft Mt. McKinley or Denali is the highest mountain in the North America. This is part of my series of "collectible mountains". All the models in this series are rendered at 1:100000. The model represents an area 10km x 10km. The bottom of the model sits at sea level so the different mountains can be accurately compared. Have you even wondered just how much bigger Everest is than Mt Shasta? Now you can hold them both in your hands and compare. If you want a model of Denali, and you don't care if it is at Collectible scale try my 20km model http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:222591
which shows the whole mountain better Complete instructions on how to make models from digital elevation data can be found on my blog at http://www.the3dprintedfuture.com/shapespeare/?p=1

My 8 year old daughter asked me to print her a flashlight using glow-in-the-dark ABS. I decided to try to do a super simple LED version which would require as few non-printable parts as possible... Seemed to come out reasonably OK and will hopefully be durable too!

• Print the parts - I did mine in glow in the dark ABS on my TOM with 25% infill. Try fitting the cap onto the battery case -- it should be a tight fit, but not so tight that it can't be opened. You may need to file or sand the parts to get the right fit.

  • You'll need the following non printable parts: 5mm white 3.3v LED (Radio Shack in the US carries them - 2 for $2.50), 2 conductive metal springs approx 6mm in diameter and 20mm long (I got mine from an assortment box I had lying around -- ideally they will fit tightly into the two holes as in the pictures), a bit of aluminum foil folded a few times, 2 AA batteries. (Pic 1)

  • Fit the LED into the center hole of the flashlight cap and carefully clip the shorter wire so it folds down neatly into the hole that does NOT have the long slot that pierces the side of the cap. Place one of the springs in the hole on top of the wire so that it contacts it firmly. (Pic 2)

  • File or sand the larger switch piece down slightly so it will fit into the slot of the cap from the inside and then be able to slide up and down without much force, but still enough friction so it stays in place. (In the picture my switch piece is red)

  • This is the tricky part; carefully clip the longer wire so that it's just long enough to fit into the tiny hole in the bottom of the switch when the switch is fit into the slot. The hole should be "down", i.e. closer to the very top of the cap. Now slide the switch all the way to the bottom -- the wire should lie in the channel below where the second spring will go so that it is not in contact with the spring. You may need to use a small screwdriver or something to get the wire to lie flat. You should probably start with the wire being too long and then clip it shorter and shorter until it fits properly. Make sure that the switch can slide up and down, moving the wire with it. (Pics 3-5)

  • Using some superglue, glue the tiny remaining tab into the top of the switch slot which will both limit the movement of the switch and prevent the switch itself from coming out. (Pic 6-7)

  • Put the second spring into the hole over the wire channel.

  • Trim the folded foil so that it fits into the bottom of the battery case and push it down to the bottom, lying flat.

  • Put the batteries in with the plus and minus poles in opposite directions

  • Put the cap onto the case so that the battery with the positive pole is closest to the switch.
    • If all is well, the LED should turn on and off with the switch!

comments.text: Update for anyone interested. I found that if you use some superglue to hold the LED tightly in place, the switch mechanism is much more reliable. I'm working on a new version that uses standard pen springs and has a more reliable switch.

title: silicone cover mold for e3d v5 clone

description.text:
you can use your heater more efficiently by covering the heaterblock with the silicone

  • better ability to hold the temperature
  • you could use stronger fans
  • plastics won't easily stick to the hotend

i was printing pc with modified e3d v5 clone hotend and since i needed at least 260c,
my hotend wasn't really showing stable temperature when printing at such high temp with high speed(usually at 100+ mm/s)
and i had problem with deformation of teflon tubes inside the hotend
i needed to stabilize the temperature but i couldn't find any products about it
so i just made one :)

you need a stick with less than 3mm in diameter, longer than 30mm
30mm m3 bolt works fine, 50mm would be better

it can be used multiple times!

Printer:

clone s270 (corexy)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1~ 0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

  • i used v tech 'vital gray' and 'vital black pro' which can be used at 300+ C
    (didn't tried permatex, but it will probably work)

  • both of them took 3 days to harden

  • i used vaseline as a remove agent and it worked fine

Instruction

  • print with 0.1 ~0.2mm layer height, i recommend 0.1mm since it is a small thing so it won't take much time and you can get better surface, and it is easier to separate

  • after printing, put some silicone in the 'body' and then put the 'core'

  • when you insert the 'core' about halfway inside the 'body', insert the m3 bolt from the hole under the 'body' to the 'core' and press the 'core' to the bottom of the 'body'

  • put some additional silicone on the top (if needed )

  • insert the 'cover'

wait for 3days

  • push the m3 bolt to pull out the mold
  • cut the front section of the mold like in the picture and pull out the mold
  • trim the mold

done!

We have an old CD cabinet that has been sitting upside-down in the corner for... I think it's been 10 years.... That can't be right can it? The problem is one of the brackets that hold the "legs" on is broken and it doesn't stand up. In an effort to prove to my family (and my self) that the RepRap that I'm spending weeks on building is actually useful, I thought that one of the first things that I would print would be this.  
Update: Five years later, this simple little bracket is my most popular thing, so I decided that I might as well make a parametric version of this. I've uploaded an scad file that should make roughly the same thing, but also allow you to make other sized l-brackets using OpenSCAD or (hopefully) the customizer.
Use like a normal l-bracket.

comments.text: What was the point of removing the shields and spinning the bearing with a drill? just curious :)
comments.author: TheKaptainFitzy

comments.text:
With the shields in place plus the grease the bearing was not free to spin easily. Great for the bearings intended use as it keeps the dirt away from the ball bearings but to slow for a spinner. You could try just pressing the unmodded bearing in place without the plastic buttons and try it, in testing I found it to be very slow.
The drill just helps to bed in the ball bearings and loosens them up, this would happen over time anyway but this speeds the process up. I think It’s better to do this with just the bearing and not spinning the finished item as that would take too long.
David

remixed_from.author: jesse
remixed_from.title: Filament measurement insert for digital thickness gauge

description.text: Measure the filament as it spools with a thickness gauge. The gauge is available on Amazon and Ebay from a variety of sellers. Here is one of the cheapest - http://www.amazon.com/gp/offer-listing/B008H1DL3M?ie=UTF8&condition=new&seller=AA3DL1YN5S7YK The guide is sized for 1.75 filament.

Screw the mount on to the intake plate using the the two holes that are closest to the top.  
Retract the plunger and slide the guide onto the "foot".   
Cut about 1.5" from the end of the PTFE tube, and then put the end of the PTFE loop into the bottom of the guide.  It's easier to slide the PTFE tube into the bottom of the guide before you put the gauge on the mount.  
Put the short bit of tube you cut off into the top of the guide.  It's necessary to have both tubes in so the filament is constrained everywhere but under the plunger.  
Put the gauge onto the mount and twist the guide to face the plate so the filament enters it as straight as possible.  Make sure the plunger still moves freely.  You might need to trim the inside a little if the plunger is rubbing against the sides.

author: BlueFlyer

title: Ikea Lack Print Box Air Circulation (using 70mm & 80mm fan)

description.text:
I'm using Ikea Lack as print box (with 100mm raiser). As expected, the hot air accumulate on top, where bottom is relatively cooler. After 10hrs printing the top is ~5'c hotter than bottom.

I made this air circulation pipes/stand which fit standard 70mm fan, to circulate the top/bottom air within the print box, to get a more even temperature.

The pipes come with 50mm / 100mm / 150mm height, one end with mounting plate to mount 70mm fan. You can print "two" and tape them together, so both end will have mounting hole.

The stand is 50mm length. You need "one" placed at the very bottom, so there is space for air to get in/out.

I would recommend you mount the 70mm fan on top, blow air upward. I found this setup caused littlest noise. That's how I'm using (as photo shows).

Nope this is not optimized for aerodynamic nor thermaldynamic :)

Edit 20170415:
I add 80mm fan version, using the same basic design. I'm now using 80mm fan setp: 50mm stand + two 150mm pipes + Noctua 80mm fan on top flow upward.

remixed_from.author: Bobylein
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Spool holder with clip

description.text:
I really liked the look of this spool holder and printed it out right away.

Something that I noticed upon installation was the slot to load the spool axle was angled rearward and a bit shallow for my liking. So I rotated that feature to vertical and lowered the bottom of the slot a couple of mm.

Also I changed up the chamfers to radii and added a locator to lock against the upper frame to take some of the load of the acrylic controller cover.

Finally I added bosses on the back side to accept a newly designed brace. This brace stabilizes one side with the other. A bit of sloppiness between the two is what I am experiencing. The brace keeps the holders apart by 100mm to the inside face.

This is a remix of a remix. The original is here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2162266

6 top and bottom layers
225C hot end
60C print bed

Assembly is a nice pressure fit with .1mm clearance designed between parts. Mine required a pair of pliers to press the joints together.

Edit 4-4-2017. I removed the brace stl due to it being too wide. Should have been 100mm between faces and not 150. Will repost modified brace.

Edit 4-5-2017. New brace_a stl was uploaded. All parts clear spool diameters and ribbon connector on the back of the controller display.

This has become part of a whole filament holding no-tool system. I have printed this spool holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2112075/#files and combined it with this axle adapter http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2228643

comments.text: The Z bracket does not fit to the JABEX 1KG Filament roll - needet to grind some mm down so the roll can move.
comments.author: Fulli

comments.text: Make sure you do not have the Z bracket inverted. It is asymmetric top to bottom.
comments.author: Fulli

comments.text: Fantastic!  This is one of the best solutions for a top mounted spool that I've come across.  Printed with no issues.  Is it possible to get a parametric file for the brace?  I'd like to remix and make it about 10mm wider.
comments.author: Indychus

comments.text: Thank you!  I printed all of the parts shown, and it is awesome!  Great design!
comments.author: jaardesign

comments.text: I just made this solution (brace, arms, nut, bolt, axle).  It fits the A8 perfectly.  However, the first spool of filament I tried (Solutech) was too big in diameter to fit.  The axle lacked about 10mm from being able to sit in the fork of the arms.  The outside diameter of the spool rests on the brace.  The spool is 20cm in diameter.  Did I get the right files?
comments.author: mlefevre

comments.text: I measured 105 mm from the center of axle to the nearest contact on the holder. I posted a picture of this measurement. If the spool is 20cm, then you should have 5mm clearance.
comments.author: mlefevre

comments.text: Hmmm.  Mine measures 98.4 mm.  I printed my braces at an angle on the bed. That doesn't seem like it should have made a difference.  Also, I printed a 20mm calibration cube that came out 20.1mm on each side so, if anything, I'm printing too big.
comments.author: dz1sfb

comments.text: That is approximately what I have. I am wondering if you have the Z brace upside down. That would take up the clearance. I am pretty sure that is what you are experiencing. There is offset to clear the spool.
comments.author: mlefevre

comments.text: Yes!  That was it.  I didn't realize that the brace was not symmetrical.  I had put it on correctly the first time, before installing a spool, but found that it interfered with the display ribbon cable less if I flipped it over.
comments.author: dz1sfb

comments.text: Where can I print the roller part?(the part that goes into the Filament)
comments.author: Cycon

comments.text: It's linked in the post printing section under the thing details tab above.
comments.author: Cycon

comments.text: Are the brace's OK on 220 x 220 hotbed -laying front to back or do they need to  turned on the diagonal?
comments.author: ABW-3D

comments.text: I was able to lay all three parts on a 220 x 220 bed. The brace can lay front to back, and the holder brackets themselves also, with one of them being angled. I like to mirror opposite side parts, but it is not necessary to do so since they are identical.
comments.author: ABW-3D

comments.text: Cool, that's exactly what I planned today at work, because I noticed the wobble too.
comments.author: Bobylein

comments.text:
Bobylein,
It's all fixed
comments.author: Bobylein

comments.text: Thanks!
comments.author: dz1sfb

comments.text: Hold off for a day on the brace. I was operating today on memory and the span for the brace should have been 100mm and not 150mm. I will redesign it for 100mm tomorrow and post it up.
comments.author: Bobylein

author: 3DFazz

description.text:
This is a work in progress.

I designed this for the way my XHovers are built. You might need to change wiring to make it work.

I use a RunCam Swift V2 camera and it fits great.

Supports required.

Print TPU.

I use M3x12MM long screws from the bottom to mount. You can also use #4x1/2" long sheet metal screws as well.

It allows for 30 degree to 60 degree camera tilt.

If you shoot panos you know that a well level shot is important to spend less time on your computer. With this thing, panos from gear 360 are always good.
You have to buy 15mm diameter bubble level like these :
http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/VvJ2rzf

Two tears of your favourite ciano glue and go!

One version with centering spots and without to use upside down.

Optimized for 0.3mm layers height.

description.text:
Upgrade your K8200 3D printer to print your ideas in clay or other pastes!

WARNING! This K8200 3D Printer add-on set requires high technical skills and is intended for experienced makers only.

find more info on the K8200 here: http://k8200.eu

comments.text: Where is the chocolate version of this setup?  Looks different and doesn't account for the heated cylinder for keeping the chocolate warm.
comments.author: ssrjazz

comments.text:
Hi ssrjazz, the chocolate version was a try-out for fairs and demonstrated how hackable the K8200 3D printer is. This demo version will not be for sale, we are sorry if you were informed otherwise.
But you can try to experiment with the paste extruder; in stead of keeping the chocolate warm, you can add more milk to the chocolate mixture to keep it liquid for a longer period of time. Then again, we're not really pastry experts but it's worth a shot!

description.text: Addi machines usually come with two metal clamps which grab the feet and then clamp to the table. I have seen several other people doing like I was and using a bar clamp to try and hold the top of the machine to the table. I designed this to cup the feet and extend them out a little. I would recommend printing them upside down so no supports will be required. Though you can see where the feet would go in and there is a space to allow the piece to go on the leg. FYI the feet measured about 32mm and the leg was about 22.5mm.

This is a 3mm thick, 20mm diameter, four holed button for use with suspenders. The edges are rounded, making this buttons a decent replacement for otherwise expensive injection molded ones. The center is also recessed, so the threads used to attach the button are flush with the top of the button.
NGSS

Requirements Having printed hundreds of buttons, and using them to attach my own suspenders to my slacks and shorts, this button is the 4th generation of designs. While you might think buttons are fairly straightforward to locate on sites like this one, it is not. So, I encourage you to give these a try. To make these, it is strongly recommended that a nylon filament is used. PLA is far too brittle for this application. ABS may be a possibility, but it is more difficult to print than Taulman 3D Bridge Nylon or Alloy 910.

Step 1: Initial Ingot Within FreeCad, create a 10mm radius circle, selecting the center point of the axes as the circle reference root. Pad this circle to 3mm. Step 2: Button Hole Generation Using one of the circle faces as a reference for a new sketch, and the axes as root references for the button holes, draw a 1.5mm radius circle on each axes approximately 3mm from the center reference used to create the original button ingot. Use dimensioning (non-construction) lines to ensure these circles are 3mm from the center root point. Pocket these holes 3mm to create the threading holes. Step 3: Recessed Center To hide the threads used to attach these buttons, draw a 2.75mm radius circle on one of the circular faces, referencing the same root point used to create the original button ingot. Pocket this circle 1mm. Step 4: Smoothing the Edges Select the large outer edges of each circular face of the button, and use a 1.5mm fillet to round the edges. This completes the part. Step 5: Printing As noted in the background, use a nylon filament to print these buttons. The nylon material such as Taulman 3D Bridge or Alloy 910 produce durable buttons that can be colored to any tint you prefer.
FreeCAD, nylon filament, computer, and a 3D printer.

title: LED Strip Holder for Under Counter Lighting

description.text:
THIS MAY NOT BE FINISHED
Many years ago, I installed under counter lighting in the kitchen. I used rope lights to light the counter on both sides of the kitchen sink. I didn't install any lights above the sink, although there was an obvious need. Enter 3D printing and small LED strips, and I found an alternate way to provide some light above the sink when you don't need the brilliance of the light fixture above the sink.

The LED holders here allow you to mount small USB powered inexpensive LED strips that are available now. I had a few of these strips on hand, so I used them:
http://www.banggood.com/LG-LED-Double-Sided-Insert-USB-Light-Ultrathin-light-p-925946.html?rmmds=search
I can't recommend these, because they may be more expensive and brighter than you need, but there are others available.
The one I would have purchased for my application is this one:
http://www.banggood.com/Wholesale-LED-Rigid-Strip-c-2772-0-1-3-45-0_page1.html?sortType=asc

There are two sizes and styles of holders for 30 and 34 mm strips. The strip fastens to the holder using a #6 sheet metal screw (or slightly smaller metric equivalent) that threads into the plated-thru hole in the strip.

The mounting frame has an opening to allow you wire to the strip on either side or both sides of the strip, and then be able to insert the prewired strips into holders that are already mounted (I used hot glue).
I used a 5v phone charger purchased at a thrift store to power the 4 strips I used. I also used a series resistor to reduce the current and achieve the low brilliance I wanted.

Depending on your application, the holders here may or may not work, but if a small change to one of the two styles here is needed, let me know and I'll post one. One change I would have made is to adjust the hole size in the holder so I could use a screw into the bracket rather than threading into the plated-thru hole in the strip (which can be difficult).

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa I3 Pro Dual

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 or .3 Layer height

Infill:

only enough to get it to print correctly

Notes:

A couple perimeters is all that is required. There isn't much strength required once they are mounted

author: LuizBello

description.text: Trango Towers in Pakistan's Karakoram range is home to the East Face of Greater Trango Tower which, at 4396ft, is the world's tallest cliff. This is part of my series of "collectible mountains". All the models in this series are rendered at 1:100000. The model represents an area 10km x 10km. The bottom of the model sits at sea level so the different mountains can be accurately compared. Have you even wondered just how much bigger Everest is than Mt Shasta? Now you can hold them both in your hands and compare. If you want a model of Trango, and you don't care if it is at Collectible scale try http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:222640 my 5km model which is cropped tighter on the towers and doesn't go all the way down to sea level. Complete instructions on how to make models from digital elevation data can be found on my blog at http://www.the3dprintedfuture.com/shapespeare/?p=1

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:217046 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=217046

Using the following options: hookRadius = o
thickness = 6.2

height = 90
holeRadius = 0
This is just a small two piece shelf. Essentially there is an insert portion you attach to the wall then the main shelf portion which slides over that to form the shelf.

You can watch a video of the printed thing at http://youtu.be/6uThGvuYpoo I made this using google sketchup, when exporting to stl I select millimeters, then have to resize by .1 in replicatorg . I don't know if that is just my setting or what, but I always have to do that. The insert on the right in the sketchup file is the one that fits, I forgot to delete the other one. I printed the the insert part at a 100%, and the shelf at 15% infill. You may want to increase the length of the insert rods, but if you aren't going to put anything heavy on it, it shouldn't be a problem. I haven't added any screw holes yet, for the insert, and I'll probably change it a bit, as the rods should be spaced a bit more as well. Possible uses, small bathroom shelves along mirror, for like shaving cream. Slight modification for external wall mounted hard drives. Speaker Shelves. Frangrance pot holder. If you print bigger, it could possible hold your router, cable modem. etc..

Trango Towers in Pakistan's Karakoram range is home to the East Face of Greater Trango Tower which, at 4396ft, is the world's tallest cliff. The sides of the model are 5km long. This tighter crop focuses in on the towers and eliminates the sea level base. If you want a collectible model of Trango check out http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:222635 Complete instructions on how to make models from digital elevation data can be found on my blog at http://www.the3dprintedfuture.com/shapespeare/?p=1

title: Project: Prusa i4 Single Z-axis motor Modification

description.text:
Project: Prusa i4 Single Z-axis motor Modification

Why:

  1. 100% synchronization of the two z- axes screws
  2. No loss in horizontal calibration of the z-axis even when one z-axis screw turned by hand accidentally.
  3. Free one z-axis driver for expansions such as a second extruder.
  4. Get a spare stepper motor may be?
  5. Use the spare stepper (and freed driver) for extra extruder??? (will upload this soon)

Steps:

1) Download and Print all the stl files attached.
2) Remove the bearing from the original holding block by tapping it off gently with a blunt object. Link:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-shipping-10pcs-lot-8mm-diameter-zinc-alloy-bearing-housing-KFL08-FL08-K08-flange-bearing-with/32363611626.html?spm=2114.01010208.3.2.UmD2Mk&ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0,searchweb201602_5_10065_10068_10136_10137_10138_10060_10062_10141_10056_10055_10054_10059_10099_10103_10102_10096_10148_10052_10053_10050_10107_10142_10051_10143_10084_10083_10080_10082_10081_10110_10111_10112_10113_10114_130_10037_10032_10078_10079_10077_10073_10070_10123_10124,searchweb201603_4,afswitch_1,ppcSwitch_5,single_sort_0_default&btsid=2204374a-198b-4e82-af4e-a0d7348ef356&algo_expid=f5950bc5-8388-4842-bfec-157112b24ff1-0&algo_pvid=f5950bc5-8388-4842-bfec-157112b24ff1

3) Fit the bearing in the bottom bearing holder printed from the stl.
4) Open and remove one z axis motor and disconnect it from the motherboard, this also frees the driver for other use.
5) Now replace the motor with the bottom bearing holder assembled in the steps above.
6) Use the gab screws to secure the z-axis screw to the bearing
7) Print two sets of the pulley and their covers and fit together
8) Drive your z-axis to the top manually with your hand,
9) Fit the two pulleys and secure in place with two screws (pulleys with holes for screw and nut) pulleys are tight fit and will require some force to be fit.
10) Print and fit the two top bearing holders and fit the bearings in to them.
11) Fit these holders on top of the installed pulleys (see pictures for clarity)
12) With the z-axis now at top most (probably touching the installed pulleys) measure a length of timing belt to fit tightly and then reduce the length by about 3 teeth. The belt can be got from here Link:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/POWGE-GT2-timing-belt-width-6mm-Rubber-2GT-6mm-used-in-linear-drive-Small-Backlash-2GT/2039635559.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.TyqFC7

13) Now splice the belt to form a ring as per this procedure Link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lT8eHz4tWyc
Notice that I did not use the kit i the video and I used standard leather glue, worked well. However, the procedure in the video produces a much cleaner result. Try it. You may also search for other splicing videos on Youtube. Its free, learn ;o)
14) Once the spliced belt cures lower the z axis down manually and fit the belt.
15) Drive the axis up manually again. Since the belt was reduced a bit (by about 3 teeth), the movement of the z-axis upward now provides full tension to the belt.
16) Tighten the Z-axis top bearing holders in place on the top rail to permanently secure the top bearing holders and tension the belt.

Modifying the Merlin Firmware:

17) Load your current firm ware in your favorite arduino IDE.
18) Open the file CONFIGURATION_ADV.h
19) look for the line below and comment it out (i.e. add // slashes before it as below)
20) //#define Z_DUAL_STEPPER_DRIVERS //Zahir - changed to use this driver for extruder 2
21) You may add custom comments as above to remind you in the future why you commented out the line.
22) It is done. Enjoy!

print_settings.Notes:: The parts are designed to be printed as shown in the picture with all of the parts together.  This will requires some manipulation in your slicer.  Obviously print as many filter housings as you need for your enclosure size.  Each housing is roughly 2 inches long.

description.text:
I wanted a filter for ABS fumes and didn't find anything to my liking, so I designed this. It prints without supports and is modular so you can add or remove "cells" according to the size of your printer enclosure in 2 inch increments. The fan supports are sized for a specific fan, but the blower end is designed so that different fan mounts can be used if a different fan is used.

I haven't used it extensively, but it does move air from the enclosure through the carbon filters, so functionally it meets requirements. Whether its use is validated will be based on experience as I print ABS parts (usually I print PLA, so experience will be slow in accumulating).

Printer:

QIDI Tech I

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

The parts are designed to be printed as shown in the picture with all of the parts together. This will requires some manipulation in your slicer. Obviously print as many filter housings as you need for your enclosure size. Each housing is roughly 2 inches long.

Additional Parts

The additional parts are a blower, filter pads, and some gasket. For the blower, I used this one: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B016UCKBUA/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I used the dimensions in the drawing for the blower, but it was still fit imperfectly. I was able to get the screws to fit with a little trimming and coercion.

For the filter pads, I used the following, but pretty much anything large enough will work:
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00L2NZOKK/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

For the gasket, I used some "gripper pad" I had laying around from a big box store. It is around 1.5mm thick, but as long as it's squishy, any material would meet the need (rubber band, bead of silicone, contact cement, thin foam, etc.)

Assembly

1) Cut your filter pads to size. For each cell, you need 2"X5.25" of filter pad.
2) Stuff the filter pads into the filter cells. How it goes in should be obvious, but there's a picture of it shown.
3) Attach the first filter cell to the blower block. Then attach the remaining filter cells and finish with an end plate.
4) Slide the top and bottom blower plates into the supplied slots in the blower block.
5) Put on your gasket material around the hole. Method to be determined by what material you use.
6) Install the blower in what should be an obvious way.
7) Find a power supply for your fan (I repurposed an old wireless router power supply)
Designed in Solidworks

Laser cut Y axis frame for MendelMax. Modified from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21638. I changed the slot width to 6mm and changed the floating rod holes from a 10mm circle to 8mm slot. This lets the rod float only in the X axis. I recommend using only one bushing on the floating rod.

comments.text: Wait, the floating rod was a 10mm circle? Hmm.. Gonna have to look into that, it should have been 8.2mm
comments.author: kludgineer

comments.text: Either way, there is no reason for the shaft to move in the Z direction.  A slot is better because it is flat on the bottom.  A circle will cause the shaft to move up whenever it moves in the X direction.  That is undesirable.
comments.author: kludgineer

description.text:
A spool stand for 1kg filament spools which have a diameter of 250mm diameter and are 55mm wide. Some assembly required.  
Feel free to adjust the uprights, top and braces to meet the dimensions you need.  
This remix replaces the base with one which hopefully uses less material and can be printed in steps in case something should go wrong. I also added things on the top to make sure the spool stays in place.

Required printing:
2x Uprights
2x Braces
2x Holders
1x Top Some filing is required for a snug fit of the uprights into the bases.
I printed in ABS using .25mm slices with 40% honeycomb infill.

title: Joy Con Thumbstick Cover - Push On

description.text:
These are a simple joystick covers for your Nintendo Switch Joy Cons. My ultimate goal for these is to sand and paint them, and as such they can be a little rough of your thumbs, but I am used to playing with metal joysticks so they are fine for me. I am going to try standard spray paint as well as plastidip and see which is more comfortable. I printed them with supports and with the bottom of the cover flat on the print bed. Here is the feature list/issues that I was trying to solve when making them.

-Simple push on design with a snug fit that does not allow the cover to wiggle or turn independent of the joystick.

-Enlarges the joystick only slightly while protruding no lower that the original joystick to still allow for full mobility of the joystick, while making it easier to grip and maneuver.

-Fashioned after a ps4 joystick with the convex hump in the middle followed by a large ridge on the outside. I also added 6 notched around the outside to give better grip when rolling your thumb around the outside. This design provides a better interior and exterior surface and grip on the joystick that the original model.

-Protect your joystick surface allowing you to simply replace the cover instead of the joystick.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed them with supports and with the bottom of the cover flat on the print bed.

Sanding and Painting

The darker purple covers were sanded with 120 grit sandpaper, then 400 grit sandpaper, primed (2 coats), painted (2 purple coats, and the misting with black) then clear coated (4 coats).

Message me if you have questions on the painting process.

description.text:
This is a logo designed by Elaine Wong for the Youth Suicide Awareness campaign "Roly-Poly Day" in Hong Kong. The campaign is organised by Mr. Chan Hung (Founder of the Principal Chan's Free Tutorial World). There is a series of lead-in activities with a concluding event taking place in Kowloon Park on April 7.

Link to the Roly-Poly facebook page
Note: the page is in Chinese.

2D poster design by Lam Ka Po, Hesper (http://hesperlam.weebly.com/)

3D modelling by Walker Cheng (https://www.facebook.com/pgeduhk)

A bit of Background

Let's admit it. We have a broken education system in Hong Kong. I am not talking about the quality of the graduates but the suicide problem of the school kids and the trend is worsening. There is just too much (unnecessary) pressure on the students nowadays in Hong Kong (and perhaps elsewhere too).

And the most worrying to us is that we are getting less and less media coverage, not to mention proper attention from the Authorities.

In February this year alone (2017), we have 7 student suicide cases. Last year we have 35 cases (corrected). For a population of around 7 million and a diminishing school kids demographic I think it's alarmingly high. I don't know how this statistic compares to other countries / cities. But even if we have just only one, isn't it "just one too many"?

Let's make some Roly-Poly's and give our students (in Hong Kong and elsewhere) some encouragement to tackle whatever difficulties they may confront. Life is too beautiful and exciting to be ended this way.

Printer Brand:

CEL

Printer:

CEL Robox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

RoboxDual is used. Some are printed with two colours in which case a brim is added to help stabilize and adhere to the bed.

Others are printed with single colour while using Polysupport for "support". Note that the support option is set to "Touch Build Plate only" (no support for the interior of the object).

We can pause the print at around 14 mm to put in a weight piece of 27-mm dia and 5-mm thick. The weight piece is required for stability.

The original Roly-Poly design is in 3 different colours - representing family (red), school (yellow) and society (blue). However, a number of white ones are produced for people to draw on as they like.

title: Cartrige/Shell for Marushin Shell Ejecting Gas Blowback Airsoft 1911 Pistols

description.text:
A friend of a friend picked up an older Marushin 1911 with the shell ejecting feature, it's neat but the shells themselves are discontinued. I modeled this off of an original shell to create a simple design that could be used for spares.
This should help people who plan to use these Marushin shell ejecting airsoft pistols in a field environment, as shells printed in PLA will be cheap to replace and will bio-degrade if lost or forgotten. You won't have to spend an hour picking shells out of the grass, or spend the rest of the day after a game staring at your loadout depressed because you lost 3 of your original, irreplaceable shells. As a result, you should actually be able to use your raresoft Maruishin instead of confining it to a display shelf.

This is version 1, which does not include the rubber retention ring present on the original shells. I had fiddled with an O-ring based retention system, but the O-rings required have a larger outer diameter than the shells themselves, so it won't work. As a result, you might be sacrificing some velocity using these.
Version 2 is in the works and will be a 2 part unit, with the bottom of the shell being printed from PLA and the top half designed to be printed from TPU or ninjaflex, so it'll have BB retention and seal similar to rubber while leaving the rim strong enough to handle the forces of the extractor mechanism.

Print from PLA at 80-100% fill density, if printing at 80%, change your printer program settings to make the first few layers solid fill, so that the rim is strong enough to handle the extraction forces.

For filament I recommend a high-visibility PLA, such as Neon green, orange or yellow. The color will make it far easier to locate shells dropped in the field, and printing them from PLA will ensure that any unrecovered shells bio-degrade in short order.

description.header: Makerbot Replicator 2X Extruder Drive Block Upgrade

description.text:
New V2 files uploaded. A few minor changes were made that should create stronger parts that require less post-finishing. Also, a remix has been created based on user comments to create a version that uses an M4 flat head screw to mount the bearing. If you would prefer to use a screw, you can find that version here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:237554

This is hopefully the last extruder drive block upgrade you'll ever need for your Makerbot Replicator 2X. It is loosely based on the function of the official Replicator 2 (not 2X) upgrade:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53125
and on the aesthetics of the whpthomas upgrade:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:79807

description.header: Advantages over other drive block upgrades:
description.text:
• Includes a fully surrounded lower filament guide hole between the drive gear and the entry to the hot end. This is ABSOLUTELY ESSENTIAL when printing with flexible filaments to prevent bending and kinking of the filament. Almost all of the other 2X upgrades are lacking this critical element.

  • Has a deeper filament guide tube hole than many others, which prevents the guide tube from slipping out while printing.

  • Requires no extra hardware for mounting the bearing. The mounting pin is included in the design, as it is in the Replicator 2 upgrade.
    • See the Instructions section for required hardware, notes, and details for a successful print and assembly.

Assembly requires the bearing and shoulder bolt from the stock extruder.
Additionally, it requires one M3 flat head cap screw (8mm length) per extruder, and a 0.375" X 1" or similar compression spring. I am currently using a spring from McMaster-Carr that works perfectly. It is part number 1986K5:
http://www.mcmaster.com/#1986k5/

description.header: NOTE:  If your extruder clicks and does not extrude, it you likely have too much spring tension.  In this case, swap the spring for a weaker or shorter one.

description.text:
• Print the base pieces. I used ABS with 3 shells, 0.15mm layer height, and .3 density supports and "doSupportUnderBridges": true. It helps to print both the left and the right at the same time so that the details of the smaller top come out better

  • Print the arm pieces. I used ABS with 4 shells, 0.15mm layer height, and 0.4 density supports with "doSupportUnderBridges": true to help the bridging of the guide tube hole.

  • print the cover pieces. I used ABS with 2 shells, 0.15mm layer height, no supports. Again, it helps to print both the left and the right pieces at the same time to allow cooling between layers

Some post-print detailing may be required to achieve the desired tolerances and fit of components.  The below is a rough guide to the drill sizes I used to finish the holes after printing.  If you don't have the bits listed, any close approximation should work fine

description.header: NOTE:  BOTH MOUNTING HOLES OF THE BASE PIECE HAVE 2 DIAMETERS.  DO NOT DRILL OUT THE SMALLER DIAMETER OF EITHER HOLE!!!
description.text:
• 1/4" end mill was carefully used to grind out the larger hole of the cover piece to get the arm to swing easily while assembled. Could also use a 1/4" drill bit
  • Number 21 drill bit (.161") was used to shape the shoulder bolt holes in the cover and arm pieces
  • Number 44 drill bit (.086") was used to shape the small filament guide holes in the arm and base pieces
  • Number 27 drill bit (.144") was used to shape the bearing peg hole in the cover piece
  • B or C drill bit (.238" or .242") was used to shape the filament guide tube hole

• Remove the extruder stepper motor from the Makerbot gantry and remove the existing extruder assembly until you are down to the bare stepper motor
  • Mount ONLY the new drive block base piece to the stepper motor using the shoulder bolt and M3 screw. Install the stepper motor into the Makerbot gantry and check the alignment of the lower guide hole with the hot end entry hole (See photo). If alignment is off, you may need to re-shape the hole with a drill bit, or re-print the part scaled up to allow for part shrinkage.
  • Ensure that the drive gear also properly aligns with the lower guide hole. If not, loosen the grub screw and slide the drive gear to the desired position on the stepper motor shaft and re-tighten
  • Unmount the stepper motor again, and fully assemble the drive block as shown in the photos, using the M3 screw in the base only, and the shoulder bolt as the arm pivot through all three parts.
  • Re-install the stepper motor with the fully assembled drive block back into the the Makerbot gantry.
  • Re-connect the cooling fan and stepper motor wires
  • Enjoy failure-free printing!

comments.text: Zits or blobs aren't going to be caused by the drive block.  I mostly only see them when using a bowden setup due to the hysteresis in the tube.  However, they can be caused by a lot of other things, such as using poor quality filament that contains air bubbles, or using filament that has absorbed too much moisture from the air.  If the blobs occur while the hot end is moving I would suspect one of those two things.  If your filament has absorbed moisture, you can dry it out in an oven for several hours at low temperature.

comments.text: This is really nicely done. I really appreciate the attention to detail such as the McMaster # and bit sizes for the holes.  Everything fit perfectly and worked great.  I have been using whpthomas' upgrade previously which was great but I wanted a few changes that yours addressed.  When I get a jam I usually pop out the spring and use a wire brush to clean the drive wheel which is easier to do with this design due to the clearance.  I removed the outer spring brace to accommodate the springs I had and to make it easier to remove. I also added a screw for the bearing since the pin snapped off.   If my mods work out I will upload the remix.  Nice work.

comments.text: Contrary to "common knowledge", I have found that my ABS prints come out much better and with less warping and curling WITHOUT using the enclosure, and even sometimes using active cooling.  I would encourage everyone to try it themselves and prove me wrong on that.  I print ABS with the top cover off and the door open and my prints come out much better than they ever did while enclosed.
comments.author: lievenstandaert

comments.text: The upgrade has been working great so thanks for that, although using it my prints are seeming to have a lot of extra filament zits on the prints. used to print ABS at 220, now down to 200 and the filament still seems to kind of just fall out of the nozzle like its too hot. any ideas on this? Thanks!
comments.author: rmcniff

comments.text: Have you heard others having similar success with removing the cover? We have a couple R2X's on campus that are having curling issues that may be interested in trying it. We have shop/lab ventilation so the downside of having more fumes/nanoparticles in the air shouldn't be a problem. (But you should be aware of that if you are printing in a semi confined space)
comments.author: rmcniff

comments.text: I have not heard anything from others printing without the cover, but I'm definitely a believer.  More air flow seems to give me much better results, provided that there is very good adhesion to the build plate.  If the adhesion is poor, it will likely cause edges to peel up worse than they would with the cover on, but the rest of the print is very much improved.
comments.author: rsparker

comments.text: Cool piece. Hope to print it soon. What kind of a build plate are you using?
comments.author: Alpha_Pi_Rho

comments.text: The build plate is a piece of window glass etched with Armour Etch and then wiped with ABS juice (acetone with dissolved ABS in it).  I then stuck it to the stock platform at the corners using 4 small pieces of 3M VHB tape.  Works great, good adhesion, very smooth flat finish, and the parts pop right off once the plate cools down.  I should create a "Thing" for that as well.
comments.author: Alpha_Pi_Rho

comments.text: Yea you should. I've been having build plate issues with my rep 2x. That seems like a good solution. Does the tape seem to out gas much when heated (smell really bad)?

title: Ikea Lack Printer Enclosure - megnetless remix

description.text:
original: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1843235

diffs:

  1. magnetless. uses slider holder on top
  2. slightly thinner walls where the glass is, so that the glass is closer to table foot.
  3. no need for supports to print the foot part and holds the glass from sliding off, but will have to glue parts together.
  4. NOT stackable as the original. two tables, one printer max.

editable and remixable in onshape here
there is a variable for glass thickness.
